bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 4, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg informs Kean about revisions to the proposed painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever,” and asks for Kean's advice. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 4, 1941
div1.opener:
Geo A Kellogg March 4/41
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
March 4, 1941
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I wish to thank you for your kind letter of February 28th. I have intended
writing you for over a week but the passage of events has been too great for
me to keep up with my correspondence.

After the delightful visit which Mr. Cornwell, Mr. Withington who, incidental-
ly, is with John Wyeth & Brother of Philadelphia, my daughter and I had with
you and Mrs. Kean, we left for Rochester to see Doctor Hench, not realizing
that he had had the more or less extensive correspondence with you concerning
the study on Yellow Fever. Doctor Hench supplied us with a great deal of in-
formation and gave us what we believe is a well balanced account of the Yellow
Fever story. Unquestionably, Mr. Cornwell and I had been under the influence
of the Cubans to too great an extent to do justice to the American Yellow Fever
Board. As Doctor Hench said, what we were offering to paint was a perfect
picture for Cuba but hardly in line with the facts and certainly not one
designed to appeal to Americans. We certainly overemphasized the importance
of Doctor Finlay.

Now we are back starting all over again. Doctor Hench would like to have the
setting on the porch of the officers' quarters at Camp Columbia and the
incident, that of Lazear allowing a mosquito to bite Doctor Carroll. This
appeals to us but for a technical reason the artist does not care to have the
scene take place on the porch. While it is not in line with the actual facts,
we would like to place Lazear and Carroll around the table just below the
porch, near one of the steps. This gives the artist an opportunity to place
several figures at various levels on the steps and makes the painting more
interesting. It is possible that Lazear and Carroll might once have fooled
around with a captive mosquito outside, although I will agree that it is not
probable. However, we wish to catch the spirit of the Yellow Fever study and
present it in a way that will give credit where credit is due. The artist
feels disappointed not to be able to use the colorful Cuban patio background
of which you saw sketches. It may develop into another picture later on.
The present one will include, in addition to Doctors Carroll and Lazear,
Doctor Reed, Doctor Agramonte, Doctor Finlay and the soldiers Moran and
Kissenger.

I just had a letter from General Truby in San Francisco in which he
suggested that we include Major General Wood. While Wood certainly
deserves some credit or, perhaps, a great deal of credit, I feel that
to include Wood would necessitate including a great many others who
also deserve credit. We don't want a mob scene, as you can well ap-
preciate. I would be interested in your opinion as to whether placing
General Wood in the picture is a necessity. We will have a good
portrait of Doctor Reed, Lazear and Agramonte and Carroll will be there.
We will also have a good portrait of Doctor Finlay and the two first
volunteers for the experiment but I am afraid I would be asking a little
too much of my artist to get a portrait of Wood into what he now con-
siders a well-crowded picture. Please don't feel that you have to agree
with me in this; we want your candid opinion and would also like your
opinion of the setting which I have described earlier in this letter.

I am glad that you are pleased with the Beaumont and Osler paintings.
Let me express my thanks again for the delightful hospitality shown us
by Mrs. Kean and yourself.

Incidentally, we had a nice visit with two of the executives of the Pan
American Union who viewed the possibility of our unveiling the Yellow
Fever picture in the Pan American Union Building favorably. Mr. Corn-
well recently had a letter from Doctor Cumming and he is much interest-
ed. I hope to see Doctor Cumming again within the next ten days or two
weeks. The Pan American Union Building is a beautiful place and would
provide a splendid setting for any ceremonies which might be arranged.

I am afraid that Doctor Hench does not think it might work out so well
since we are withdrawing the emphasis in the painting from Doctor Finlay
but I have a feeling that the people connected with the Pan American
Union will take a fair attitude in this matter.
With kindest personal regards, I am,
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George A. Kellogg George A. Kellogg
EM
